block.p: Barak Makes Overture To Likud, Which Rejects It Prime Minister Ehud Barak said that if peace talks with the Palestinians failed he was prepared within ''a few weeks'' to invite the conservative opposition to join in a broad government of ''national unity.'' The proposal was rejected by the leader of the opposition Likud, Ariel Sharon, who had been suggested by Mr. Barak as a possible foreign minister in a coalition government.

'Black Boxes' Found in Bahrain Bahraini authorities and United States Navy divers based in the Persian Gulf recovered the flight data and cockpit voice recorders in the shallow waters near where Gulf Air Flight 072 crashed on Wednesday, killing all 143 aboard. Neither recorder appeared damaged, Bahrain's civil defense chief said.

U.S. Islamic Leader Assailed A Turkish state security court has issued an arrest warrant for Fetullah Gulen, a 62-year-old moderate Islamic religious leader who lives in Pennsylvania. He is accused of inciting his followers to plot the overthrow of Turkey's secular government.

Mexican Leader in Washington President-elect Vicente Fox Quesada discussed his vision of a virtually borderless North America with President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore. He is to meet with Gov. George W. Bush in Texas today.
Mexico's Supreme Court ordered President Ernesto Zedillo to give lawmakers secret banking data relating to questionable financing of Mr. Zedillo's 1994 campaign.

Complaints of Kremlin Meddling Rear Adm. Einar Skorgen of Norway told a Norwegian newspaper that Norway almost called off its rescue efforts for the sunken submarine Kursk because of interference and misinformation by Russian officials.

Evangelicals Arrested in China One hundred and thirty followers of the China Fangcheng Church, including three visiting Americans, were said to have been arrested at a Christian revival in central China.

Scientist in Secrets Case Is Granted $1 Million Bail A federal judge said Wen Ho Lee, who is accused of mishandling nuclear secrets at the Los Alamos National Laboratory, could be released on $1 million bail pending his trial. The judge said the government case against Dr. Lee ''no longer has the requisite clarity and persuasive character.'' Dr. Lee could remain in custody for a week or so while the judge's tough conditions, amounting to home detention, are finalized.

Target of Indian Ire Indians across the country are using new affluence from casino operations to finance an effort intended to deny a fourth term to Senator Slade Gorton, Republican of Washington. Mr. Gorton and Indians have long fought over issues like fishing rights and power over tribal affairs.

Bush Campaign Split on Tactics The cancellation of a Republican Party television ad attacking Al Gore's trustworthiness has exposed tensions within the Bush campaign over whether to go negative against the vice president now.

Gov. George W. Bush used people he presented to campaign audiences to illustrate his contention that Mr. Gore's tax-cutting plan was so narrow and complicated that it would not lower taxes for many middle-class people. Mr. Gore's aides derided Mr. Bush's examples as selective and misleading.
Cheney Defends Performance Dick Cheney forcefully defended his work in the oil services business, bristling at any suggestion that he was less than successful as the chief executive of Halliburton.
Estate Tax Bill Sent to Clinton Republicans sent a bill to repeal the federal estate tax to the White House, where a veto is expected.

Charity Is Linked to Hamas The State Department has asked the Agency for International Development to withdraw its registration from one of the largest Muslim charities in the country, the Holy Land Foundation for Relief and Development, saying it has ties to the terrorist group Hamas, government officials say.

Lazio Offers Alternative To Bush Tax Cut Plan Representative Rick A. Lazio moved to distance himself from Gov. George W. Bush's tax cut plan, proposing a package of reductions that his campaign said was nearly 40 percent smaller than the Bush presidential campaign is promoting.
Ruling Backs City on Air Tours A federal judge upheld a ban on an air charter company's use of an East River seaplane base for tours.
Seeking Life's Origins An experiment mimicking the violent interactions of deep-seated rock and common gases just after Earth formed supports a maverick theory of how life began on the planet.

A Threat to Dogs, and People A strain of leishmaniasis, a disease normally spread by sandflies and one that has killed humans in other countries, is responsible for the deaths of foxhounds in Dutchess County, N.Y. The disease has not been found in other kinds of dogs, or in people, in the United States.
City-State Dispute Resolved The New York City Board of Education agreed to place up to 400 certified teachers in vacancies at poorly performing elementary schools.
Racial Disparity in Tests Grows A gap between test scores of black and white students that narrowed through the 1980's widened from 1990 to 1999, federal data shows.

Ewing Likely to Stay a Knick General Manager Scott Layden said he expected Patrick Ewing to start the season in New York, and he essentially shut the door on any semblance of the complex trade that would have sent Ewing to Seattle.
Comets Edge Liberty Houston beat New York, 59-52, in Game 1 of the W.N.B.A. finals.

Medical 'Buyers' Clubs' on Rise A variety of new companies are beginning to offer below-market prices on prescription drugs and services like doctor, dental and eye care and medical tests, mainly to people who have no health insurance or whose insurance does not cover them.

'Survivor' Gives CBS a Lift The final episode reached more than 50 million viewers, eclipsing every show of any kind on television in the last year except for the Super Bowl. The success of the series sets CBS up for some enormous payoffs.

Phone Strike Leaves Backlog Verizon and the last 35,000 union workers on strike reached a settlement late Wednesday after an 18-day walkout. It will take the company almost twice that long to work through its backlog of repairs and orders.
Report on Auto Fuel Use A coming government report offers few conclusions on the effects of tightening fuel-economy regulations, dimming prospects that Congress will change them this year.

Ford Fires Back at Tire Critics Ford officials accused lawyers suing the automaker and Bridgestone/Firestone of endangering public safety by urging a broader tire recall and of distributing Ford documents out of context to journalists.
Editorials: Air rage; a smart African itinerary; sensible rules for stem cell research; Verlyn Klinkenborg on ''Survivor.'' Columns: Gail Collins.
